body: Yes all images are letterboxed (resized and padded) to `img-size` during training.
Thank you for your reply. So if I train by img-size 256 all images will be 256 or 416?

@sanazss `python3 train.py --img-size 256` will resize all of your images to 256x256 with padding added to the short side. Aspect ratio is maintained. See https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/issues/232#issue-435736281
Thanks. So if all my images are same size I don’t need to apply the letterbox for padding. Right?
@sanazss letterboxing is automatically applied if needed. If not needed its not applied.

Thank you for your answer Glenn. I have another question about the configuration file. I use yolov3-1cls cfg file which has an image size of 416. so does that mean the input image size would be resized to 416 in the network? should change the image size in cfg file?
@sanazss the training settings in the cfg are not used. cfg is only used to define model architecture. Training settings are defined in train.py.

issue.title: Question about image size

repository.name: yolov3
repository.description: YOLOv3 in PyTorch > ONNX > CoreML > TFLite

issue.body:
I want to train my custom dataset with resolution 2880×540.
So how can I change the image size to this? After reading this (#456) , maybe I should add --img_size 2880 in training command line, so the letter box may automatically resize it to 2880×544. Is that right?
Thank you for help.

body:
@joel5638 hmm I don't understand. Are running python on the edge device? Is this iOS or Android?

The normal worflow would be to export to onnx, and then from there to coreml or tflite.

issue.title: How does yolov3 deal with images of variable size?

repository.name: yolov3
repository.description: YOLOv3 in PyTorch > ONNX > CoreML > TFLite

issue.body:
## ❔Question
Hello, thanks a lot for your great work, I really appreciate it! I have a question regarding the implementation of yolov3. According to [this](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/issues/456) and [this issue](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/issues/511), yolov3 resizes the images to imgsz * imgsz duing training, unless --rect is used, but test.py and detect.py automatically uses rectangular inference. So that means that the size of images at test time can be different from the size of images used for training, and that images of different sizes can be used for inference. Am I correct? If yes, how does that work exactly? Wouldn't changing the size of images at test time make the shape of the outputs of the final layer different? I tried to read through the code but couldn't find the part where this is made possible. I would greatly appreciate it if you could explain how this works. Thank you very much!

## Additional context
